 Is she overdoing it? Mabye. Maybe not. I think straight people fail to understand just how humiliating such an expericence can be. Plus, she's not his only patient. Maybe she's just a ###### off regular person who can throw it off and just wants to put a stop to it, but I can guarantee that the doctor has patients who could truly be harmed by something like this.
 
 When I was 14, I got crabs. I had never had sex. Had never made out with anyone, boy or girl. Had never kissed anyone. My best guess is that I got them from sitting on a couch at a friends house... his parents were hippies and not big on hygiene. I was utterly grossed out and went to the doctor. Being an Army dependent, that meant going to Fitzsimmons Army Hospital in Denver. The doctor figured I was lying and grilled me in a "hey, we're guys here" sort of way about having had sex with a girl (a not unreasonable assumption on his part). He kept at it, figuring that there must be something behind my quite obvious and deep embarrassment. He was all, "come on, you can tell me" and "it's ok, nothing to be ashamed of for a young man". Well, naive little twerp that I was -- ever so trusting in authority figures -- and kind of offended that he didn't believe I was a good little boy (cuz, god knows I was a good kid), I told him that I was telling the truth and that I didn't even want to make out with a girl, let alone have sex with her. That led to questions, which led to honest answers (still in twerp mode). What that led to left me spending my evenings sitting on the parapet of our five-story apartment building considering tossing myself off. It could have been worse, he could have recommended "treatment". As it was, he said he never wanted to treat me again.

 I criticize reparative therapy (you used the term again so I will, too) as a "solution" to being gay. It certainly isn't that. It might be a way for a very, very small number of people to deal with the conflict between their sexuality (homo or hetero) and a deep, deep guilt associated with sexual feelings. Personally, I'd rather folks like that get treatment for their obsessive or extreme religious views, but I would leave that choice to them and to the psychological professional working with them. A lot of people do seek legitimate counseling. In almost all cases, the choice is to work on adapting to life as a gay person, not to squelch the gay stuff.
 
 As for reparative therapy "working", I think there's plenty of evidence that it doesn't work in almost any case, certainly not in the way it's advertised (and it IS advertised by all sorts of anti-gay organizations -- another group you should take up your argument with).
 
 I now know you think I, like all other gay people you know, am a near basketcase so I might just be making this up, but I've known two gay men who sought out "reparative therapy" (there I go, using your side's term again). One did so for religious reasons -- he really was burdened with incredible guilt. The other wasn't trying to stop being gay, he just wanted to get married (white picket fence, etc.) and thought the only way to get that was marrying a woman. 
 
 The former is now a pastor at a gay church. He's still in therapy about the guilt, but he's stopped trying to be someone he isn't and he hasn't tried to kill himself in years. The latter married a woman (who was fully aware of what she was getting into). They divorced amicably after two years. Having given up on marrying a woman and seeing no hope of finding a good man, he promptly crossed paths with one and has been "domesticated" for going on 12 years now.
 
 Those two resolutions strike me as "successes" in that the people are happier now, fully conscious of their choices, maturely and honestly making life decisions in light of their needs and wants. Of course, they're failures from the "reparative therapy" POV. 
 
 
That's what I hear, but then I find many of those "studies" don't draw the proper distinctions about what's really going on in the reparative therapy, and they assume the conclusions of their studies apply to ALL forms of the philosophy rather than the clinical-psychological forms of reparative therapy. And the studies tend to be conducted by gay rights-affiliated groups.

 
 I'm sure you can point us to "good" studies. Feel free...

One of the reasons a certain poster is instantly identifiable, no matter which forum he infests or handle he assumes, is because he's absolutely unique in persisting to claim--in the face of repeated and absolutely indisputable rebuttals--that (among other bizarre assertions):
 a) Republicans are more pro-gay than Democrats
 
 b) That he himself is pro-gay (possibly the most hilarious of his claims)
 
 c) That "gay activists" invented the term "reparative therapy."I have no interest in re-visiting the first two of these surreal assertions. (Though I'm sure he'll come around to them again. He seems to assume everyone forgets the last time he was roundly rebutted on them, and routinely brings them up again after waiting a "decent interval." Wash, rinse, repeat.)
 
 In unarguable disproof of the third, however: 

 Book: Reparative Therapy of Male Homosexuality, by Joseph Nicolosi, PhD (Nicolosi, by the ways, is one of the foundersof NARTH. Heard of NARTH? Know what they do there--or claim to do?)
 http://www.narth.com/docs/repair.html
 
 Book: Healing Homosexuality -- Case Stories of Reparative Therapy
 http://www.leaderu.com/orgs/narth/cases.html
 
 Article on Leadership U website: Journal Articles Support the Reparative-Therapy Treatment Optionhttp://www.leaderu.com/orgs/narth/journalarticle.html
 If he is seriously implying that NARTH and Leadership University are pro-gay, someone's relatives should seek intervention.
 
 It is worth noting, by the way, that none of the above, nor any other anti-gay website that uses the term, puts the term in quotes--indicating irony--which the vast majority of pro-gay cites that refer to it, do. (As BobNelson2 points out, why on earth would pro-gay people coin a term that specifically describes what they staunchly maintain it doesn't do--"repair"??) Nor, in any of the above, do the authors, say "Well, I'm using the term because gay activists foisted on me" or offer a similar disclaimer.
 
 It's their term. They invented it. Case closed.
 
 The poster's repeated insistence of the contrary, so easily and often disproven, on here and other fora, over a period of years--(along with the fact that he's mysteriously so bugged by it that he feels it necessary to do it again and again) is clearly indicative, IMO, of the level of dementia of which so many rabid anti-gay activists are possessed.
doG

No double standard because there are a few square miles in the entire country where two men can hold hands in public while a man and woman can hold hands anywhere without comment (even in those few gay square miles)? What WOULD constitute a double standard????

 Everyone treating gays unfairly. In reality there's a percentage of the people that are bigots and/or gay bashers but they don't represent anyone but themselves. 
 
 
Civility? Politeness? Minding-your-own-business-ness?

 If you must. I personally express my opinion when I feel the need without concern for offending someone. I also tolerate offensive expressions, lest I would be a hypocrite myself. If I supress my opinion it's only because I choose to do so, not because anyone else wants me to.
BobNelson2

Everyone treating gays unfairly. In reality there's a percentage of the people that are bigots and/or gay bashers but they don't represent anyone but themselves. 

 
 What silliness. By your definition, there is no such thing as a double-standard anywhere for anything.
jyoshu

One of the reasons a certain poster is instantly identifiable, no matter which forum he infests or handle he assumes, is because he's absolutely unique in persisting to claim--in the face of repeated and absolutely indisputable rebuttals--that (among other bizarre assertions):
 
 a) Republicans are more pro-gay than Democrats
 
 b) That he himself is pro-gay (possibly the most hilarious of his claims)
 
 c) That "gay activists" invented the term "reparative therapy."

 
 I don't get it. NO one here has made the first and third claim at all. And a lot of people feel that the second applies to them; it depends on what one's take is on the issue. Honestly, who the heck are you posting about, here? Were you replying or referring to me?
 
 Are you sure you're reading the same thread? emoticon_wow
jyoshu

Once again, back to square one. "Reparative therapy" is a term YOUR side made up

 
 I never said either side came up with the term, nor does it really matter to me. No matter who came up with it, your movement still does a #### poor job of being specific about what you're talking about nearly every time the term is used.
 
 
That aside, I don't understand your point. This thread is about a doctor's office handing out info to ALL patients they perceive or know to be gay.

 
 So, you don't think the issue of reparative therapy is pertinent to this discussion?
 
 
I criticize reparative therapy (you used the term again so I will, too) as a "solution" to being gay.

 
 That's fine, you are free to criticize it all you want. I just think it's interesting that you essentially, for all practical purposes, might as well be calling every person who says they pulled it off a liar. Based on your OWN experiences, and certainly not on their's since you aren't privy to them.
 
 It's odd that on THIS matter you refuse to accept people's word, about THEIR lives even, assuming you know more about THEIR situation than they themselves do. Is it so hard to simply admit that if a person claims they've changed, maybe, just maybe, they really did?
 
 
As for reparative therapy "working", I think there's plenty of evidence that it doesn't work in almost any case

 
 Again, depends on what you mean by the term, and that's why I criticize your movement for not being specific about what you mean when you USE the term. If you mean the psychological tactics, you're probably right. If you mean people learning to live against being gay, and learning that life doesn't have to be about gay sex and attractions, then you are certainly wrong. People have done that for a LONG time.
BobNelson2

I never said either side came up with the term, nor does it really matter to me. No matter who came up with it, your movement still does a #### poor job of being specific about what you're talking about nearly every time the term is used.
 
 So, you don't think the issue of reparative therapy is pertinent to this discussion?
 
 That's fine, you are free to criticize it all you want. I just think it's interesting that you essentially, for all practical purposes, might as well be calling every person who says they pulled it off a liar. Based on your OWN experiences, and certainly not on their's since you aren't privy to them.
 
 It's odd that on THIS matter you refuse to accept people's word, about THEIR lives even, assuming you know more about THEIR situation than they themselves do. Is it so hard to simply admit that if a person claims they've changed, maybe, just maybe, they really did?
 
 Again, depends on what you mean by the term, and that's why I criticize your movement for not being specific about what you mean when you USE the term. If you mean the psychological tactics, you're probably right. If you mean people learning to live against being gay, and learning that life doesn't have to be about gay sex and attractions, then you are certainly wrong. People have done that for a LONG time.

 
 You get YOUR side to be more specific, then we'll be more specific. Honestly, the wide gamut of "therapies" we're referring to can all be -- and are all -- called "reparative therapy" by the folks who do that sort of thing. Take up your argument with them.
 
 On the larger issue, do you just ignore all the places where I say people are free to choose to be "ex-gay" (which I would call "straight") if they want to? Of course you do. I'd even say it's a good solution to their internal conflicts (though rarely, if ever, the best).
 
 Unlike YOU, I wouldn't even call them all "borderline basket cases" (or whatever you said about all the gay people you have ever met).
 
 
 
 
So, you don't think the issue of reparative therapy is pertinent to this discussion?

 
 Considering all your whining about misuse of the term, don't you think YOU ought to be more specific????

title: 4Forums.com Political Debates and Polls -  doctor passing out anti gay propaganda
